title: Lynn man convicted of killing girlfriend whose body was found in Saugus marsh
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Bruce Maiben of Lynn was sentenced to life without parole for the murder of his girlfriend, Sherell Pringle.
Sherell Pringle's body was discovered in the Rumney Marsh Reservation in Saugus in December 2021.
Maiben was initially charged with larceny and tampering, later charged with murder after Pringle's disappearance.

title: Debt holders take over downtown Boston office building sold below value
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: 99 Bedford St. in downtown Boston sold for $19 million, below its assessed value of $22.4 million.
Chevron Partners LLC and Capital Hall Partners won the auction, planning to renovate and maintain it as office space.
The City of Boston was the runner-up bidder, aiming to convert the building into housing as part of downtown revitalization.

title: Bruins’ Fraser Minten is starting to see his stock rise in Marco Sturm’s system
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Fraser Minten has scored four points in his last five games, increasing his prominence within Marco Sturm's system.
Minten was promoted to a top line with David Pastrnak and Marat Khusnutdinov during the game against the Islanders.
The Bruins' 4-3 shootout win over the Islanders showcased Minten's impact, including his average ice time growing over 15 minutes.

title: All the new movies and TV shows streaming in November
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Netflix releases 'Stranger Things' Season 5 Part 1 on November 26.
HBO Max streams 'Fantastic Four: First Steps' from November 5.
Ari Aster's film 'Eddington' available on HBO Max starting November 14.

title: Tom Brady refuses to pick sides in Patriots Buccaneers matchup
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Tom Brady declines to choose sides in upcoming Patriots-Buccaneers matchup, both former teams of his.
Patriots and Buccaneers lead their divisions with strong records, Patriots 7-2 and Buccaneers 6-2.
Brady ranks both teams in his NFL top 10, with Patriots at 6th and Buccaneers at 3rd this week.

title: South Shore woman loses over $30,000 in arrest warrant scam
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A Weymouth woman was scammed out of $31,600 by someone claiming to be a lieutenant with an arrest warrant.
The victim wired $20,500 and $6,500, and sent $4,500 and $100 via Apple Pay before realizing the scam.
Norfolk County Sheriff warned that local police do not call with arrest warrants and advised reporting such calls to police.

title: 29-year-old driver killed in crash that closed Route 1 Wednesday morning
author: John Waller
bullets: A 29-year-old driver died in a crash on Route 1 in Norwood, closing the road Wednesday morning.
A 47-year-old driver was hospitalized with non-life-threatening injuries following the Route 1 crash.
The crash in Norwood closed Route 1 for several hours; the road reopened shortly after 11 a.m.

title: Boston police now required to wear nametags under new contract extension
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston Police Department patrol officers are now required to wear nametags under a new contract extension.
The contract covers July 1, 2025, to June 30, 2026, with a cost of $6.7 million.
The agreement includes wage increases, free gym access, and a more thorough officer evaluation system.

title: The backlash has arrived: 6 takeaways from a good night for Democrats
author: Reid J. Epstein, The New York Times
bullets: Democrats won major elections in Virginia, New Jersey, California, and flipped seats in Georgia, rebuking Trump's influence.
Zohran Mamdani won the New York City mayoral race, exemplifying a new strategic approach for progressive Democrats.
California's ballot measure, pushed by Governor Gavin Newsom, will favor Democrats in upcoming redistricting battles.

title: The Swedish candy craze has taken Boston by storm. Here’s where you can get it.
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Swedish candy gains popularity in Boston after a viral TikTok, with locals buying from stores like Madeleine's and The Sweetish Fish.
Madeleine's Candy Shop offers 50 pick-and-mix bins with sweet and sour gummies for $1.50 per ounce, including popular Bubs candy.
The Sweetish Fish hosts a pop-up in Boston's Seaport, selling Swedish candy by the ounce and offering daily specials called the "Daily Catch."
